"2025 U.S.–Houthi ceasefire")<br>        <br>*   [2025 Houthi attack on Tel Aviv airport](/wiki/2025_Houthi_attack_on_Tel_Aviv_airport "2025 Houthi attack on Tel Aviv airport")<br>    <br>*   [May 2025 Israeli attacks on Yemen](/wiki/May_2025_Israeli_attacks_on_Yemen "May 2025 Israeli attacks on Yemen")<br>    <br><br>Deaths<br><br>*   [Alim Abdallah](/wiki/Alim_Abdallah "Alim Abdallah")<br>    <br>*   [Issam Abdallah](/wiki/Issam_Abdallah "Issam Abdallah")<br>    <br>*   [Saleh al-Arouri](/wiki/Saleh_al-Arouri "Saleh al-Arouri")<br>    <br>*   [Ali Hussein Barji](/wiki/Ali_Hussein_Barji "Ali Hussein Barji")<br>    <br>*   [Razi Mousavi](/wiki/Razi_Mousavi "Razi Mousavi")<br>    <br>*   [Wissam al-Tawil](/wiki/Wissam_al-Tawil "Wissam al-Tawil")<br>    <br>*   [Sadegh Omidzadeh](/wiki/Sadegh_Omidzadeh "Sadegh Omidzadeh")<br>    <br>*   [Mushtaq Talib Al-Saeedi](/wiki/Mushtaq_Talib_Al-Saeedi "Mushtaq Talib Al-Saeedi")<br>    <br>*   [Mohammad Reza Zahedi](/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Zahedi "Mohammad Reza Zahedi")<br>    <br>*   [Fuad Shukr](/wiki/Fuad_Shukr "Fuad Shukr")<br>    <br>*   [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")<br>    <br>*   [Ibrahim Aqil](/wiki/Ibrahim_Aqil "Ibrahim Aqil")<br>    <br><br>Related topics<br><br>*   [Iran–Israel proxy conflict](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict "Iran–Israel proxy conflict")<br>    <br>*   [Hezbollah–Israel conflict](/wiki/Hezbollah%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Hezbollah–Israel conflict") |     |

On 1 October 2024, [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")
 launched about 200 [ballistic missiles](/wiki/Ballistic_missile "Ballistic missile")
[\[16\]](#cite_note-Schneider-2024-16)
 at targets in [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
, in at least two waves, then the largest attack during the ongoing [Iran–Israel conflict](/wiki/2024_Iran%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "2024 Iran–Israel conflict")
.[\[17\]](#cite_note-nytimes-17)
 Iran's codename for the attack was **Operation True Promise II** ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language")
: عملیات وعده صادق ۲).[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)
 It was the second direct attack by Iran against Israel, the first being the [April 2024 strikes](/wiki/April_2024_Iranian_strikes_against_Israel "April 2024 Iranian strikes against Israel")
.

Iran claimed that the attack was an act of "self-defense"[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)
[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)
 in [retaliation](/wiki/Reprisal "Reprisal")
 for Israel's assassinations of [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
 leader [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")
 in [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
, [Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
 leader [Hassan Nasrallah](/wiki/Hassan_Nasrallah "Hassan Nasrallah")
, and [IRGC](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 general [Abbas Nilforoushan](/wiki/Abbas_Nilforoushan "Abbas Nilforoushan")
. Hamas-lead militant groups killed 1,139 Israelis, while Israel killed 41,000 Palestinians, mostly women and children.[\[32\]](#cite_note-Gadzo-32)
 On October 8, Hezbollah joined the conflict in solidarity with the Palestinians, promising to stop attacking Israel, if Israel stops attacking Gaza.[\[32\]](#cite_note-Gadzo-32)
 During the war Iran has repeatedly accused Israel of carrying out [genocide in Gaza](/wiki/Gaza_genocide "Gaza genocide")
,[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)
[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)
 and threatened Israel with "far-reaching consequences if it didn't stop [its war crimes](/wiki/Israeli_war_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "Israeli war crimes in the Gaza war")
.[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)

### Previous attacks inside Iran and Israel

Main articles: [Israeli airstrike on the Iranian consulate in Damascus](/wiki/Israeli_airstrike_on_the_Iranian_consulate_in_Damascus "Israeli airstrike on the Iranian consulate in Damascus")
, [April 2024 Iranian strikes against Israel](/wiki/April_2024_Iranian_strikes_against_Israel "April 2024 Iranian strikes against Israel")
, and [April 2024 Israeli strikes on Iran](/wiki/April_2024_Israeli_strikes_on_Iran "April 2024 Israeli strikes on Iran")

On 1 April, Israel aircraft attacked the Iranian consulate in Damascus,[\[36\]](#cite_note-Tanyos-2024-36)
 killing two Iranian generals,[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)
 seven [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 (IRGC) officers,[\[36\]](#cite_note-Tanyos-2024-36)
 and a Syrian woman and her child.[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)
 Iran retaliated on 13 April by launching attacks against [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 with [loitering munitions](/wiki/Loitering_munition "Loitering munition")
, [cruise missiles](/wiki/Cruise_missile "Cruise missile")
, and [ballistic missiles](/wiki/Ballistic_missile "Ballistic missile")
. Hajizadeh mentions that the [Supreme Leader of Iran](/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran "Supreme Leader of Iran")
 specifically asked [IRGC](/wiki/IRGC "IRGC")
 to not accidentally hit or target [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
 members during the missile attack

An [Iranian Parliament](/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly "Islamic Consultative Assembly")
 representative comments on Iranian missile strikes against [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
, the morning after the attack, 2 Oct 2024

Iran's vice president for Strategic Affairs [Javad Zarif](/wiki/Javad_Zarif "Javad Zarif")
 contended that Iran had the right to self-defense against Israeli attacks on Iranian soil and criticized Western countries for aiding "the Israeli [genocide in Gaza](/wiki/Gaza_genocide "Gaza genocide")
" and acquiesing "in Israeli aggressions against Iran, Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, Yemen and other countries in the region".[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)
 Iran's Foreign Minister further added the missile strikes targeted "solely military & security sites in charge of genocide".[\[31\]](#cite_note-IRNA-English-2024-31)

According to the IRGC, Iran has threatened to carry out "crushing attacks" if Israel responds.[\[111\]](#cite_note-hindustantimes-112)
 Khamenei is reported to be staying in a secure location.[\[112\]](#cite_note-113)
 Iran said that 90% of its missiles had hit their targets, but the Israeli military disputed this claim, saying that "a large number" of missiles were intercepted.[\[25\]](#cite_note-bbc.com-25)

Iranian state media alleged that up to 20 F-35 fighter jets were destroyed in the strike and that the [Nevatim Airbase](/wiki/Nevatim_Airbase "Nevatim Airbase")
 was heavily damaged.[\[113\]](#cite_note-114)

Iran suspended all flights at [Imam Khomeini International Airport](/wiki/Imam_Khomeini_International_Airport "Imam Khomeini International Airport")
 following the missile attacks.[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)

Crowds celebrated the strikes in [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
 and other cities, waving the Hezbollah, Iranian, [Palestinian](/wiki/Flag_of_Palestine "Flag of Palestine")
 and [Lebanese flags](/wiki/Flag_of_Lebanon "Flag of Lebanon")
 while holding portraits of Hassan Nasrallah.[\[115\]](#cite_note-Al-Jazeera-2024-116)

While leading Friday prayers at the [Grand Mosalla mosque of Tehran](/wiki/Grand_Mosalla_mosque_of_Tehran "Grand Mosalla mosque of Tehran")
 on 4 October, Khamenei described the strikes as "minimum punishment" for Israel's "astonishing crimes".[\[116\]](#cite_note-117)
 On 6 October, Khamenei awarded General [Amir Ali Hajizadeh](/wiki/Amir_Ali_Hajizadeh "Amir Ali Hajizadeh")
, commander of the [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Aerospace Force](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps_Aerospace_Force "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Aerospace Force")
, with the [Order of Fath](/wiki/Order_of_Fath "Order of Fath")
, citing the force's conduct of the strike.[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)

#### Israel

[Minister of Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Israel) "Ministry of Finance (Israel)")
 [Bezalel Smotrich](/wiki/Bezalel_Smotrich "Bezalel Smotrich")
 commented on the situation, stating, "Like Gaza, Hezbollah and the [state of Lebanon](/wiki/Lebanon "Lebanon")
, Iran will regret the moment."[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)

[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel "Prime Minister of Israel")
 [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
 stated that Iran made a "big mistake" and that Israel will attack its enemies anywhere in the Middle East.[\[119\]](#cite_note-politico-120)
[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)
 During the attacks, the [Security Cabinet of Israel](/wiki/Security_Cabinet_of_Israel "Security Cabinet of Israel")
 convened in a bunker in [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem")
.[\[97\]](#cite_note-Parker-2024-98)

IDF Chief of Staff Lt. He suggested that if Israel retaliates significantly, it would be in Iran's interest to absorb the blow rather than escalate tensions.[\[21\]](#cite_note-Trofimov-2024a-21)

The [Institute for the Study of War](/wiki/Institute_for_the_Study_of_War "Institute for the Study of War")
 said that the strikes were likely intended to inflict significant damage through oversaturating Israeli air defenses as Iran used more ballistic missiles, as opposed to slow moving cruise missiles, a large number of missiles used to oversaturate Israel's air defense system, and the cost of the missiles made the strikes unlikely just for show.[\[160\]](#cite_note-161)
[\[161\]](#cite_note-162)

_[The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist "The Economist")
_ noted that the attack appeared to be an attempt to "overwhelm Israel's missile-defence systems by force of numbers," but it "failed almost completely," as "most of the missiles were intercepted and destroyed in mid-air. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20241004023243/https://carnegieendowment.org/emissary/2024/10/iran-israel-missile-attack-nuclear-strategy-what-now?lang=en)
     from the original on 4 October 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20241002042322/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/us-has-indications-iran-preparing-launch-ballistic-missile-attack-israel-2024-10-01/)
     from the original on 2 October 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20241007091744/https://www.timesofisrael.com/west-denounces-irans-ballistic-missile-attack-cautions-against-further-escalation/)
     from the original on 7 October 2024."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article states that on October 1, 2024, Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel. Israel said that the coalition whose defensive efforts were codenamed Iron Shield destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons. The Economist noted that the attack appeared to be an attempt to "overwhelm Israel's missile-defence systems by force of numbers," but it "failed almost completely," as "most of the missiles were intercepted and destroyed in mid-air."

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf): 
Content: "JINSA October Missile Attack Proves Costly for Iranian Regime 3 » Assuming Iran fired 180 missiles and used similar missile variants in the attack, Israel’s figures demonstrate that Iran’s medium-range ballistic missiles (MRBMs) cost the regime at least $12 million apiece—far costlier than previous public estimates. JINSA October Missile Attack Proves Costly for Iranian Regime 1 NatSec Brief: December 6, 2024 October Missile Attack Proves Costly for Iranian Regime Ari Cicurel Assistant Director of Foreign Policy Yoni Tobin Policy Analyst Iran has threatened another strike against Israel in recent days. Iran’s October 1 ballistic missile attack cost the regime around $2.3 billion, at least four and six times the estimated cost (and at least 124 and 42 times more in terms of GDP per capita) for the United States and Israel, respectively, to defend against it. According to a Tasnim sum- mary of his remarks, Larijani said, “relevant officials \[in Iran’s\] military and government are preparing measures to show \[a\] proper response to recent Israeli aggression against Iran.” » Iran’s previous direct attack against Israel—its October 1 missile strike—inflicted minimal damage despite Iran launching approximately 180 ballistic missiles into Israeli airspace. That changed with Iran’s October 1 missile attack against Israel, which cost Tehran relatively more to execute than it cost Israel and the United States to defend against, while yielding minimal tactical or strategic success for the regime. ⚫ On November 12, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that Iran’s October 1 missile attack cost the Iranian regime $2.3 billion. Costs of October 1 Missile Attack Israel United States Iran Low-End Estimated Cost of Missile Attack $360,000,000 $116,400,000 $2,300,000,000 (Number provided by Israel) High-End Estimated Cost of Missile Attack $630,000,000 $334,000,000 GDP Per Capita (2023 est.) World Bank Figures $52,260 $81,695 $4,502 ⚫ Given that around 180 missiles entered Israeli airspace in the attack, the maximum conceiv- able cost for Israel to defend against Iran’s October 1 attack—assuming a ratio of one inter- ceptor fired per inbound missile—was significant but smaller than Iran’s: between $360 mil- lion and $630 million, according to JINSA estimates. » Israel’s wide-ranging October 26 kinetic response reportedly involved some 100 aircraft, targeted over 20 sites, took out key elements of Iran’s ballistic missile program—includ- ing planetary mixers used to make solid fuel for MRBMs—and neutralized Iran’s primary air defenses, leaving Iran’s core assets vulnerable to future strikes. Iran’s attack also incurred a strong Israeli re- sponse that knocked out the regime’s main air defenses and elements of its ballistic missile and nuclear programs. JINSA October Missile Attack Proves Costly for Iranian Regime 2 In addition, the attack proved costly in tactical terms for Iran, yielding serious IDF blowback that compromised key elements of the regime’s nuclear programs and ballistic missile pro- duction programs, and took out the regime’s top air defenses."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
JINSA published a report on December 6, 2024, stating that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion. The cost for Israel to defend against the attack was between $360 million and $630 million.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586): 
Content: The search result from jpost.com discusses the technological lessons learned from the Iran war. The article was published on July 20, 2025. <image:1>


From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel): 
Content: The Wikipedia article states that on October 1, 2024, Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel. Israel said that the coalition whose defensive efforts were codenamed Iron Shield destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons. The Economist noted that the attack appeared to be an attempt to "overwhelm Israel's missile-defence systems by force of numbers," but it "failed almost completely," as "most of the missiles were intercepted and destroyed in mid-air."


From [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf): 
Content: JINSA published a report on December 6, 2024, stating that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion. The cost for Israel to defend against the attack was between $360 million and $630 million.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)

_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `misleading`: The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the claim or image is misrepresented in a wrong context or the necessary context is omitted. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way. If the claim refers to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content and/or meaning of the image.If the claim is a text-only claim, i.e. it does not refer to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content, and/or meaning of a statement.
* `not enough information`: The claim is marked as NEI when there is not enough evidence to verify the claim or if the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory. 
* `false`: The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


## Elaboration
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results reveal conflicting information about the interception rate of ballistic missiles during the October 1, 2024, Iranian attack on Israel. While one source mentions a 99% interception rate, the claim of 90% cannot be verified with the available evidence.

`not enough information`

_________________________



PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

Israel’s air-defense system passes test in fending off Iranian missile strike
=============================================================================

[World](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world)
 Oct 2, 2024 1:49 PM EDT

JERUSALEM (AP) — Israel’s multilayered air-defense system appears to have passed another test after fending off Iran’s latest missile barrage.

In Tuesday’s night’s strike, Iran fired over 180 missiles toward Israel. According to Israeli media reports, the cost of a single Iron Dome interception is about $50,000, while the other systems can run more than $2 million per missile. It has been deployed on multiple occasions throughout the war.

### Iron Dome

This system, developed by Israel with U.S. Israel says it has a success rate of over 90%.

### Iron Beam

Israel is developing a new system to intercept incoming threats with laser technology. They have ranged from short-range rockets to medium-range missiles to attack drones to long-range ballistic missiles like those fired Tuesday night.

**WATCH:** [Middle East again on edge after largest aerial attack ever launched against Israel](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/middle-east-again-on-edge-after-largest-aerial-attack-ever-launched-against-israel)

In Tuesday’s attack, the U.S. Explosions also were seen over the skies of Jordan, though it remains unclear who carried out the interceptions.

But the vast majority of Israel’s air defense over the past year has been carried out by Israel itself. Israeli leaders say the system isn’t 100% guaranteed, but credit it with preventing serious damage and countless casualties.

Here’s a closer look at Israel’s multilayered air-defense system:

### The Arrow

This system developed with the U.S. is designed to intercept long-range missiles, including the types of ballistic missiles Iran launched on Tuesday."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
PBS News Hour published an article on October 2, 2024, discussing the Iranian missile strike on Israel. The article states that Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. It mentions that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90%. <image:227>

[World News](https://apnews.com/world-news)

Iranian missile strikes show Israel’s aerial defense array is not ironclad
==========================================================================

Iranian missile strikes show Israel’s aerial defense array is not ironclad
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

1 of 3 | 

Air raid sirens sounded across Israel on Friday night as Iranian missiles were launched towards the country. assistance, has developed a tiered system capable of detecting incoming fire and deploying only if the projectile is headed toward a population center or sensitive military or civilian infrastructure while letting other projectiles land in open spaces.

The array can shoot down short-range rockets to medium-range missiles to attack drones to ballistic missiles like those Iran has been firing.

But the military warns the system is not fool proof and while interception rates are generally high, enemy missiles can penetrate. Israel has said this system will be a game changer because it would be much cheaper to operate than existing systems.

According to Israeli media reports, the cost of a single Iron Dome interception is about $50,000, while the other systems can run more than $2 million per missile. Supreme Court](https://apnews.com/hub/us-supreme-court)

# Your Summary

The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


## Elaboration
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.


## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome interception rate Iran attack October 1 2024")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/israels-air-defense-system-passes-test-in-fending-off-iranian-missile-strike): 
Content: PBS News Hour published an article on October 2, 2024, discussing the Iranian missile strike on Israel. The article states that Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. It mentions that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90%. <image:227>


From [Source](https://apnews.com/article/israel-air-defense-f0e72fa1c1dba6bc08fcc0bfb0c5a9f0): 
Content: The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. The article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof and that interception rates are generally high, but enemy missiles can penetrate. The article was published on June 19, 2025. <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
PBS News Hour reported that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024, when Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. The article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof and that interception rates are generally high, but enemy missiles can penetrate. The article was published on June 19, 2025.

*   [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/israels-air-defense-system-passes-test-in-fending-off-iranian-missile-strike)
*   [Source](https://apnews.com/article/israel-air-defense-f0e72fa1c1dba6bc08fcc0bfb0c5a9f0)

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


## Elaboration
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.


## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome interception rate Iran attack October 1 2024")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
PBS News Hour reported that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024, when Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. The article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof and that interception rates are generally high, but enemy missiles can penetrate. The article was published on June 19, 2025.

*   [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/israels-air-defense-system-passes-test-in-fending-off-iranian-missile-strike)
*   [Source](https://apnews.com/article/israel-air-defense-f0e72fa1c1dba6bc08fcc0bfb0c5a9f0)

<image:227>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The PBS News Hour article states that the Iron Dome had a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. This supports the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles. However, the Associated Press article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof, and enemy missiles can penetrate.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `misleading`: The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the claim or image is misrepresented in a wrong context or the necessary context is omitted. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way. If the claim refers to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content and/or meaning of the image.If the claim is a text-only claim, i.e. it does not refer to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content, and/or meaning of a statement.
* `not enough information`: The claim is marked as NEI when there is not enough evidence to verify the claim or if the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory. 
* `false`: The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


## Elaboration
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.


## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome interception rate Iran attack October 1 2024")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
PBS News Hour reported that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024, when Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. The article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof and that interception rates are generally high, but enemy missiles can penetrate. The article was published on June 19, 2025.

*   [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/israels-air-defense-system-passes-test-in-fending-off-iranian-missile-strike)
*   [Source](https://apnews.com/article/israel-air-defense-f0e72fa1c1dba6bc08fcc0bfb0c5a9f0)

<image:227>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>


## Elaboration
The PBS News Hour article states that the Iron Dome had a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. This supports the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles. However, the Associated Press article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof, and enemy missiles can penetrate.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence from PBS News Hour supports the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted over 90% of the missiles during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. The Associated Press article also supports the claim, but it also mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof.

`true`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The Iron Dome intercepted 90% of ballistic missiles fired at Israel in Iran's attack on October 1, 2024."

## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome Israel ballistic missile interception rate October 1 2024 Iran attack")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include an article from jpost.com discussing technological lessons learned from the Iran war, published on July 20, 2025 (<image:1>). Another source, a Wikipedia article, mentions that Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, 2024, and Israel's defensive efforts destroyed 99 percent of the incoming weapons.

A report from JINSA, published on December 6, 2024, states that Iran launched approximately 180 ballistic missiles at Israel on October 1, resulting in minimal damage. The report estimates the cost of the attack to Iran at $2.3 billion.
*   [Source](https://www.jpost.com/defense-and-tech/article-861586)
*   [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel)
*   [Source](https://jinsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/October-Missile-Attack-Proves-Costly-for-Iranian-Regime-1.pdf)


## Elaboration
The evidence provides conflicting information regarding the interception rate of ballistic missiles. The Wikipedia article states that 99% of the incoming weapons were destroyed, while the jpost.com article does not specify an interception rate. Therefore, the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles cannot be verified with the provided evidence.


## Actions
```
web_search("Iron Dome interception rate Iran attack October 1 2024")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
PBS News Hour reported that the Iron Dome has a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024, when Iran fired over 180 missiles at Israel. The Associated Press published an article discussing the Iranian missile strikes on Israel, with images of the Iron Dome intercepting missiles. The article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof and that interception rates are generally high, but enemy missiles can penetrate. The article was published on June 19, 2025.

*   [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/israels-air-defense-system-passes-test-in-fending-off-iranian-missile-strike)
*   [Source](https://apnews.com/article/israel-air-defense-f0e72fa1c1dba6bc08fcc0bfb0c5a9f0)

<image:227>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>


## Elaboration
The PBS News Hour article states that the Iron Dome had a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. This supports the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted 90% of the missiles. However, the Associated Press article mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof, and enemy missiles can penetrate.


## Final Judgement
The evidence from PBS News Hour supports the claim that the Iron Dome intercepted over 90% of the missiles during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. The Associated Press article also supports the claim, but it also mentions that the Iron Dome is not foolproof.

`true`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is supported by evidence from a PBS News Hour article, which states that the Iron Dome had a success rate of over 90% during the Iranian missile strike on October 2, 2024. An Associated Press article also supports the claim, although it notes that the Iron Dome is not foolproof.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

## Actions
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-image-claims-show-141025316.html): 
Content: "(Photo by Amir Levy/Getty Images)

An image [shared on X](https://x.com/ArabiBenarab/status/1883645963967045808)
 claims to show an Israeli Merkava tank modified into a fruit stand in Gaza.

> [](https://twitter.com/ArabiBenarab/status/1883645963967045808?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

**Verdict: False**

The tank is a Syrian T-55, not an Israeli Merkava tank. It was taken in Syria.

**Fact Check:**

Social media users are claiming to show an Israeli Merkava tank in Gaza, modified into a fruit stand. [!CheckYourFact <image:2075>](https://checkyourfact.com/)

Elias Atienza

*   [](http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aol.com%2Ffact-check-image-claims-show-141025316.html%3Fsoc_src%3Dsocial-sh%26soc_trk%3Dpin&description=FACT CHECK: Image Claims To Show Israeli Tank Modified Into A Fruit Stand In Gaza "Pinterest")
    
*   [](https://share.flipboard.com/bookmarklet/popout?v=2&title=FACT CHECK: Image Claims To Show Israeli Tank Modified Into A Fruit Stand In Gaza&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aol.com%2Ffact-check-image-claims-show-141025316.html%3Fsoc_src%3Dsocial-sh%26soc_trk%3Dflipboard "Flipboard")
    

!An Israeli tank moves a long the border with the Gaza Strip on January 1, 2025 in Southern Israel, Israel. (Photo by Amir Levy/Getty Images) <image:2076>

An Israeli tank moves a long the border with the Gaza Strip on January 1, 2025 in Southern Israel, Israel. One user wrote, “The Merkava tank is the most famous Israeli military industry. In Gaza, they made it into a Gazan fruit and vegetable stall. It also identifies the location as Homs, not Damascus.

“The army left a tank… for almost three days, I brought the goods, but no one saw the shop,” Youssef says in the video.

Furthermore, the tank is a [T-54/55](https://odin.tradoc.army.mil/WEG/Asset/T-54_Russian_Main_Battle_Tank_(MBT)
), not a Merkava tank. A Merkava tank has a [flatter turret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkava)
 than the Soviet-era tank, which was [widely used](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_equipment_of_the_Syrian_Army)
 by the Syrian Arab Army.

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. <image:2075>, <image:2076>

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

| Crew | 4 (tank commander, driver, gunner, loader). It was judged to be a significant improvement over Israel's formerly most effective main battle tank, the [Centurion](/wiki/Centurion_tank "Centurion tank")
.[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)
 Israel lost dozens of tanks during the conflict, including several Merkavas.[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)

### Second Intifada

In February 2002, a Merkava III was destroyed by a roadside bomb near [Netzarim](/wiki/Netzarim "Netzarim")
 in the Gaza Strip. The IDF wanted to increase orders of new Merkava Mark 4 tanks, and planned to add the [Trophy active defense system](/wiki/Trophy_(countermeasure) "Trophy (countermeasure)")
 to Merkava Mark 4 tanks, and to increase joint training between crews and Israeli [anti-tank](/wiki/Anti-tank_warfare "Anti-tank warfare")
 soldiers.[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)
[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)

### Operation Cast Lead

Main article: [Operation Cast Lead](/wiki/Operation_Cast_Lead "Operation Cast Lead")

The Merkava Mark IV was used more extensively during the [Gaza War](/wiki/Gaza_War_(2008%E2%80%932009) "Gaza War (2008–2009)")
, as it had been received by the IDF in increasing numbers since 2006, replacing more of the Merkava II and III versions of the tank that were in service. The Trophy protective system has been used by the IDF since 2011.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Storming_Ahead.jpg/250px-Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Storming_Ahead.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Storming_Ahead.jpg)

Merkava IV equipped with the [Trophy](/wiki/Trophy_(countermeasure) "Trophy (countermeasure)")
 active defense system.

By October 2010, the IDF had begun to equip the first Merkava Mark IVs with the Trophy active protection system, to improve the tanks' protection against advanced anti-tank missiles which use [tandem-charge](/wiki/Tandem-charge "Tandem-charge")
 HEAT warheads.[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)
[\[63\]](#cite_note-weiss-63)
 Added protection systems included an Elbit laser-warning system and IMI in-built smoke-screen grenades.[\[29\]](#cite_note-Merkava_Mk_IV_breaks_cover-29)

In December 2010, [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
 fired an [AT-14 Kornet](/wiki/AT-14_Kornet "AT-14 Kornet")
 anti-tank missile at a Merkava Mark 3 tank stationed on the Israel-Gaza border near Al-[Bureij](/wiki/Bureij "Bureij")
. As a result of the attack, Israel decided to deploy its first Merkava Mark 4 battalion equipped with the Trophy system along the Gaza border.[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)

On March 1, 2011, a Merkava Mark IV stationed near the Gaza border, equipped with the Trophy active protection system, successfully foiled a missile attack against it, marking the system's first operational success.[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)

### Operation Protective Edge 2014

Main article: [Operation Protective Edge](/wiki/Operation_Protective_Edge "Operation Protective Edge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Merkava4m-Windbreaker-0036a.jpg/250px-Merkava4m-Windbreaker-0036a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merkava4m-Windbreaker-0036a.jpg)

Merkava Mk 4M Windbreaker, fitted with [Trophy](/wiki/Trophy_(countermeasure) "Trophy (countermeasure)")
 [active protection system](/wiki/Active_protection_system "Active protection system")
, during [Operation Protective Edge](/wiki/2014_Israel%E2%80%93Gaza_conflict "2014 Israel–Gaza conflict")

No tanks were damaged during Operation Protective Edge. _(May 2024)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal")<br>)_ |

Some Merkava tanks are fitted with full medical and ambulance abilities while retaining their armament (but carrying less ammunition than the standard tank, having both ammunition racks in the rear removed). The Loader Keyboard Panel (LKP) includes breech block closing switch, fire and local activation of the trays.

The main operational roles are: firing from internal storage; firing for elevator – ground-piled ammunition; loading from elevator – external pile; synthesising fire programs; unloading; manual firing; identification; and fusing and checks.

Standard equipment includes an NBC system of the overpressure type and an inertial navigation and aiming system designed for autonomous operations.

According to Soltam Systems, the 155 mm/52 caliber ordnance and automatic loader, or parts of the system, could be installed in other self-propelled artillery systems and used to upgrade other self-propelled systems such as the US-designed and built 155 mm [M109](/wiki/M109_howitzer "M109 howitzer")
 and [M44](/wiki/M44_self_propelled_howitzer "M44 self propelled howitzer")
.

Successor (Carmel)
------------------

On July 14, 2011, _[The Jerusalem Post](/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Post "The Jerusalem Post")
_ reported that the IDF had begun developing a successor for the Merkava series of tanks. With the system's ability to intercept threats at a stand-off distance, there was a review of the need for vehicles like the Merkava to have thick, heavy layers of armor.[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)

The Merkava Tank Planning Directorate set up a team to study principles for a future tank and present ideas for an armored fighting vehicle to provide mobile firepower on a future battlefield. [Jump to content](#bodyContent)

[![Extended-protected article](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8c/Extended-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Extended-protection-shackle.svg.png)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#extended "This article is extended-confirmed-protected")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Series of Israeli main battle tanks

For the religious/mystical uses of the word, see [Merkabah](/wiki/Merkabah "Merkabah")
.

| Merkava |     |
| --- | --- |
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Merkava-Mk4m-whiteback01.jpg/330px-Merkava-Mk4m-whiteback01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merkava-Mk4m-whiteback01.jpg)<br><br>Merkava Mk 4M Windbreaker, equipped with the [Trophy active protection system](/wiki/Trophy_(countermeasure) "Trophy (countermeasure)")<br>, during [Operation Protective Edge](/wiki/Operation_Protective_Edge "Operation Protective Edge")<br> 2014."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces. It has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War. <image:43> shows a Merkava Mk 4M Windbreaker, equipped with the Trophy active protection system.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/15/hamas-distributed-a-handy-guide-to-destroying-israeli-tanks/): 
Content: "[](https://www.forbes.com/)

Hamas Distributed A Handy Guide To Destroying Israeli Tanks

By[David Axe](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/ "https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/")

Share

SaveComment

[Business](https://www.forbes.com/business/)
[Aerospace & Defense](https://www.forbes.com/aerospace-defense/)

Hamas Distributed A Handy Guide To Destroying Israeli Tanks
===========================================================

By[David Axe](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/ "https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/")
,

Former Staff.

David Axe writes about ships, planes, tanks, drones and missiles.

Oct 15, 2023, 11:19pm EDT

Share

SaveComment

Hamas's anti-tank flyer.

Via social media

Hamas terrorists think they know how to knock out the Israeli army’s main tank, the 70-ton Merkava Mark IV.

Aim for the rear hatch and ammunition-stowage, the space between the turret and hull, the tank’s belly or a supposed weak spot in the armor on the side of the hull near the front. The ammo storage, turret ring and belly are weak spots on virtually _all_ tanks.

What’s more surprising is Hamas’ tips for defeating the Trophy active protective systems that are new features on some of the Israeli army’s roughly 400 front-line Merkava Mark IVs. Alternatively, an SPG-9 recoilless gun should defeat a Trophy-equipped tank, simply by virtue of its projectile’s high speed.

There is some evidence of Hamas militants damaging a Merkava with an PG-7T rocket on Oct. It’s possible the terrorists dutifully followed the flyer’s advice; it’s _also_ possible they defeated the tank’s Trophy by firing several rounds in quick succession—and overwhelming the device.

In any event, it wasn’t RPG teams who claimed the most Merkavas on Oct. Hamas’ small drones [struck at least two](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/12/israels-merkava-mark-iv-tanks-are-more-drone-proof-than-other-tanks-are/?sh=172138352114 "https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/12/israels-merkava-mark-iv-tanks-are-more-drone-proof-than-other-tanks-are/?sh=172138352114")
 of the heavily-armed, thickly-armored tanks. Another hit a Merkava on the turret bustle, which holds spare 120-millimeter cannon rounds for the four-person crew.

And the militants also _captured_ a Merkava—[along with more than a dozen superheavy armored personnel carriers](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/12/israel-converted-captured-arab-t-55-tanks-into-heavy-personnel-carriers-hamas-just-captured-a-tenth-of-them/?sh=60c212994a84 "https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/12/israel-converted-captured-arab-t-55-tanks-into-heavy-personnel-carriers-hamas-just-captured-a-tenth-of-them/?sh=60c212994a84")
—at an Israeli army base in Nakhal Oz. The terrorists abducted hundreds more people in settlements near the Israeli wall surrounding Gaza.

The Israelis retrieved at least one of the flyers, apparently from a dead Hamas fighter, and posted photos on social media.

The flyer’s contents should come as no surprise to experienced soldiers. One aimed its payload at the thin armor protecting the tank’s engine in its forward hull. You don’t need help from a flyer when a tank is crewless and idle.

[Got a tip? Share confidential information with Forbes.](https://www.forbes.com/tips/)

[Editorial Standards](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesstaff/article/forbes-editorial-values-and-standards/)
[Reprints & Permissions](https://www.parsintl.com/publications/forbes/)"

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks. The article mentions that Hamas militants damaged a Merkava with a PG-7T rocket and that Hamas captured a Merkava.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

## Actions
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-image-claims-show-141025316.html): 
Content: The image shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. <image:2075>, <image:2076>


From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkava): 
Content: The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces. It has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War. <image:43> shows a Merkava Mk 4M Windbreaker, equipped with the Trophy active protection system.


From [Source](https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2023/10/15/hamas-distributed-a-handy-guide-to-destroying-israeli-tanks/): 
Content: The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks. The article mentions that Hamas militants damaged a Merkava with a PG-7T rocket and that Hamas captured a Merkava.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image (<image:43>) shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces and has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War.

The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

## Actions
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The image (<image:43>) shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces and has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War.

The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks.


### Evidence from `reverse_search`
From [Source](https://en.haberler.com/in-syria-an-abandoned-tank-has-become-a-fruit-and-2027395/): Found exact image on website with title: In Syria, an abandoned tank has become a fruit and vegetable stand.
Content: The search result is from a Turkish news website and shows an image of a tank used as a fruit and vegetable stand in Syria. The article is dated December 15, 2024. <image:2101> The article mentions the Syrian regime's collapse and the "Operation Dawn of Freedom" in December 2024.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is inaccurate. The image depicts a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank. The vegetable stand is located in Syria, not Gaza. The image was taken before January 2025, as indicated by the December 15, 2024, date of the Turkish news article.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `misleading`: The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the claim or image is misrepresented in a wrong context or the necessary context is omitted. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way. If the claim refers to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content and/or meaning of the image.If the claim is a text-only claim, i.e. it does not refer to an image, it misrepresents the origin, content, and/or meaning of a statement.
* `not enough information`: The claim is marked as NEI when there is not enough evidence to verify the claim or if the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory. 
* `false`: The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

## Actions
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The image (<image:43>) shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces and has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War.

The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks.


### Evidence from `reverse_search`
From [Source](https://en.haberler.com/in-syria-an-abandoned-tank-has-become-a-fruit-and-2027395/): Found exact image on website with title: In Syria, an abandoned tank has become a fruit and vegetable stand.
Content: The search result is from a Turkish news website and shows an image of a tank used as a fruit and vegetable stand in Syria. The article is dated December 15, 2024. <image:2101> The article mentions the Syrian regime's collapse and the "Operation Dawn of Freedom" in December 2024.


## Elaboration
The claim is inaccurate. The image depicts a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank. The vegetable stand is located in Syria, not Gaza. The image was taken before January 2025, as indicated by the December 15, 2024, date of the Turkish news article.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim misidentifies the tank as an Israeli Merkava tank when it is a Syrian T-55 tank. It also incorrectly states the location as Gaza and the date as January 2025, while the image is from Syria and was taken before January 2025.

`misleading`
_________________________



SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:43> This image shows a vegetable stand in Gaza in January 2025 with a Merkava tank, the pride of the Israeli army, as its decor."

## Actions
```
web_search("vegetable stand Gaza Merkava tank")
reverse_search(<image:43>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The image (<image:43>) shows a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank, modified into a fruit stand. The photo was taken in Syria, not Gaza. The article was published on February 3, 2025. The Merkava tank is a main battle tank used by the Israel Defense Forces and has been used in several wars, including the Gaza War.

The Forbes article, published on October 15, 2023, discusses a flyer distributed by Hamas on how to destroy Israeli Merkava tanks.


### Evidence from `reverse_search`
From [Source](https://en.haberler.com/in-syria-an-abandoned-tank-has-become-a-fruit-and-2027395/): Found exact image on website with title: In Syria, an abandoned tank has become a fruit and vegetable stand.
Content: The search result is from a Turkish news website and shows an image of a tank used as a fruit and vegetable stand in Syria. The article is dated December 15, 2024. <image:2101> The article mentions the Syrian regime's collapse and the "Operation Dawn of Freedom" in December 2024.


## Elaboration
The claim is inaccurate. The image depicts a Syrian T-55 tank, not an Israeli Merkava tank. The vegetable stand is located in Syria, not Gaza. The image was taken before January 2025, as indicated by the December 15, 2024, date of the Turkish news article.


## Final Judgement
The claim misidentifies the tank as an Israeli Merkava tank when it is a Syrian T-55 tank. It also incorrectly states the location as Gaza and the date as January 2025, while the image is from Syria and was taken before January 2025.

`misleading`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image shows a Syrian T-55 tank used as a vegetable stand in Syria, not an Israeli Merkava tank in Gaza, as claimed. The photo was taken before January 2025, as evidenced by a Turkish news article from December 15, 2024, which can be found [here](https://en.haberler.com/in-syria-an-abandoned-tank-has-become-a-fruit-and-2027395/).
